|Title=Know how to prevent PPH
|Description=Know the risk factors and directed delivery
|Heading=Management
|Contributors=Paul Berveiller,Philippe Deruelle
|Order=7}}

It includes:

- directed, ''systematic'' delivery: ''prophylactic administration of oxytocin (APO)'' as soon as the child is discharged (5 to 10 IU IVL of oxytocin);

- the use of a "blood loss collection bag" just after expulsion to assess the volume of blood loss;

- normal delivery monitoring

- systematic monitoring for 2 hours in the labour ward

- artificial delivery if the placenta fails to detach 30 minutes after delivery

- macroscopic inspection of the placenta and membranes after delivery.

question.question: What is the recommended approach to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
question.option_a: Administering oxytocin only after the placenta has been delivered
question.option_b: Prophylactic administration of oxytocin (APO) as soon as the child is discharged, along with systematic monitoring for 2 hours in the labour ward and macroscopic inspection of the placenta and membranes after delivery
question.option_c: Using a 'blood loss collection bag' only after the placenta has been delivered
question.option_d: Artificial delivery if the placenta fails to detach 30 minutes after delivery, without any other preventive measures
